Coups. On April 21, 1964, Brasilia‘s airport remains closed, and roadblocks are established as local police halt gasoline sales and commerce, likely due to a government order amid a general strike. A mass meeting supports President Goulart, announcing a call-up for military reservists. Attendance is exaggerated, with government-controlled radio reporting 10,000 workers, though actual numbers are likely 5,000-6,000.

SOC Social Conditions 1967 (Classified) On May 17, 196?, an outgoing report from the U.S. Consulate in Recife discussed media coverage of a school construction agreement signed by the ambassador. Despite hand delivery of the press release, local papers did not publish it in time. Only one paper mentioned the story, leading to disappointment. Feedback on radio and newspaper placements was awaited.

Local Reaction to Brazilian Change of Government )RIGIN/ACTION  M/ R  / REFt A F  ,R A EUR FE  J E A  9 CU 1NR  E P  / 10  L F BO  C /( AID  J/J  *1 J>//'  / VGR COM FRB  INT LAB TAR  TR XM B AIR  k RM Y CIA  10 NAVY  3 OSD USI A  r NSA  )fl:JE4 DEPARTMENT OF STATE  FOR RM USE ONLY  A-8U1 CONFIDENTIAL  HANDLING INDICATOR  TO DEPARTMENT OF STATE  INFO: BASRA, RIO DE JANEIRO  ;.i,t LLPMRTIVIENT OF STATE  DISTRIBUTION BUREAU OF  i INTER-Afv'iERICAN AFFAIRS  DATE:APREPR,294864 FROM Amembassy BAGHDAD  SUBJECT : Local Reaction to Brazilian Change of Government  REF Depcirtef't836  r "l  The Brazilian coup was reported over Baghdad radio and was head­ lined in all Baghdad papers April 2. There were a few factual accounts  of the events in press and radio for the next two or three days when they  were displaced entirely by Arab problems.  The official Iraq News Agency made no comment but al-Jumhuriya, the  government press organ, carried a short editorial on the subject April 3.  The paper pictured the Brazilian events as being a struggle between the  left and the right which is "far from finished". It said that there was  no doubt that "Goulart enjoyed considerable popular support" but it added  (rather surprisingly in view of traditional condemnation of any relatively  pro-Western revolutionary activity) that "the forces of capitalism, and  with them a large section of the military and of the intelligentsia, see  in the American way of life an example worthy of emulation. Consequently,  they frown on any form of Castroism. To them, leftist Goulart was an  enemy who had to be disposed of at any price."  There were no other editorials.  For the Ambassador:  William C. Lakeland  First Secretary of Embassy  GROUP 3  Downgraded at 12-year intervals,  not automatically declassified. The document discusses local reactions in Baghdad to the Brazilian coup reported on April 2. While the official Iraq News Agency remained silent, al-Jumhuriya portrayed the events as a conflict between left and right forces. It claimed that despite popular support for Goulart, capitalism supporters in Iraq viewed him as an enemy of the American way of life.

HANDLING INDICA TOR  FROM : AmEmbassy Office - BRASILIA "APR 111967  DATE: April 10, 1967  SUBJECT: Military Court Rejects IPM Which Indicted Archbishop  of Brasilia  REF : Brasilia's A-38 of October 11, 1966  r "I 1. The referenced airgram reported the submission to the  military court system of the results-of the Police-Military  Inquiry (IFM) Into the pro-Goulart radio programs broadcast in  Brasilia at the time of the 136H Revolution. The Archbishop  of Brasilia, Dom Jose NEWTON de Admelda, had been included in  the list of those accused by the IPM of infraction o'f the  National Security Lav/, along with the former head of the Civil  Household, Darci Ribeiro, and others.  2. On April 5, the Superior Military Court (SuperiorTribunal  Militar - STM) voted to throw the entire IPM report out of  court. In the words of the reporting justice, Minister Alcides  Carneiro, "The public prosecutors in Brasilia judged that the  results of the inquiry should be rejected on the grounds of  the absence of any illegal act. In this record, there are no  proofs; so there is no guilt to be determined. The path of  this IPM is to the dust of the archives."  3. The decision was taken by a tie vote, automatically broken  in favor of the defendants by the presiding justice, Gen.  Olimpio Mourao Filho. The Attorney-General for Military  Justice, however, in his opinion to the court, had recommended  that the Archbishop be excluded from the IPM and that the  process be handed down to the military court of the 4th  Military Region in Juiz de Fora for prosecution of the other  defendants. Presumably, those on the court who voted against '.  the complete rejection of the IPM results nonetheless supported  the Attorney-General's opinion absolving the Archbishop. Midkiff SOC 12-1 BRAZ 1/1/67 On April 5, 1967, Brazil‘s Superior Military Court rejected an inquiry into pro-Goulart radio broadcasts that had implicated Archbishop Dom Jose Newton de Admelda and others. The court found no evidence of wrongdoing. The case was dismissed by a tie vote in favor of the defendants, with the Attorney-General recommending the Archbishop‘s exclusion from the proceedings.

The document is an official communication from the U.S. Embassy in Rio de Janeiro to the State Department, summarizing a televised interview with President Médici on February 27. He denied promising a return to full democracy by the end of his term, stated it was premature to revoke certain measures, and commented on state governors‘ ability to pursue other offices without misusing their current powers.

Opposition Convictions that Costa e Silva Will Not Become President of Brazil MEMO TO PILES  POL - Frank C, Carlucci  Opposition Convictions that Costa e Silva Hill Not Become  President of Brazil  1* During the past week and a half the reporting officer has  had lengthy conversations with four prominent local members  of the opposition and believes it worth noting for the record  that all spontaneously expressed the conviction that Castello  Branco does not want Costa e Silva to be the next President  of Brazil and will try to out«msneuvar him after Costa e Silva  leaves the War Ministry on July 2, These statements may rep- resent wishful thinking on the part of the opposition but they  were made In a positive and forceful tone unusual for Brazilian  politicians, Cuanabara Assembly MDB Leader Paulo S&bciio* for  example, said that he is "absolutely certain" that Castello  Branco would find a way to eliminate Costa e Silva*a candidacy,  2, The specific scenario outlined by each of the opposition  members varied slightly *  (a) Guanabara State Deputy (e*»PSD) Luiz Gonzaga da Gama  Fllho, who plans to run this year for Federal Deputy, imagined  a ploy Whereby Castello Branco would name a War Minister per*  sonally loyal to him, who in turn would state publicly on the  eve of the elections that the Array would guarantee the inves­ titure of any candidate elected, Gama Fllho anticipated that  tilth such a guarantee a number of ARENA Deputies would side  with the MDB if the latter could produce an acceptable candi­ date. He was somewhat vague on who such a candidate might be  but suggested Carvalho Pinto as a possibility,  (b) Candido Antonio Mendes de Almeida, a prominent  leftist intellectual, formerly associated with Quadros,  admitted that the biggest obstacle to derailing Costa e Silva  was Castello Branco*s moral commitment, But, he said, Castello  Branco Is being told night and day that Costa e Silva is unfit  to be President of Brazil and that he, Castello, must stop him.  Since Candido is a close personal friend of General Golberry,  it can be assumed that the SHI chief is one of those feeding  COHFlDKlfriAL HAM?** • MOW Receives  in am „  t,,eBla June 21, 1966  ' *£R|CAR EMBASSY  DECLASSIFIED  Authority UMD.^iST POL 14 Elections A memo from Frank C. Carlucci discusses local opposition beliefs that President Castello Branco will prevent Costa e Silva from succeeding him after July 2. Various scenarios are presented regarding potential candidates to unify opposition support against Silva.

D.K. Ludwig Plans to Harvest a Jungle Business abroad  BRAZIL  D. K. Ludwig plans to harvest a jungle  34 Multibillionaire Daniel K. Ludwig,  never a man to plan on a small scale,  has a monumental new gamble going  in Brazil's Amazon basin. In the last  four years he has sown more than $30- million into a vast commercial refores­ tation scheme on a 2.4-million acre  tract. Ultimately he will put at least  $60-million into his huge tree farm, but  already the 74-year-old U. S. tycoon has  become the biggest investor in one of  the world's last frontiers.  Ludwig is taking a plunge into a  realm of tropical agriculture never be­ fore attempted on such a scale.  And the scheme, operating under  the shroud of secrecy that is a  Ludwig trademark, has Brazil­ ians fascinated. "The project is so  grandiose that you would expect  it only from a national govern­ ment," says an American diplo­ mat in Brazil. "Ludwig is accus­ tomed to investing in lunatic  adventures, and just as accus­ tomed to having them pay off,"  says noted Brazilian economist  Roberto Campos.  Ludwig moves with the bold­ ness of a Howard Hughes and  owns more shipping tonnage  than Aristotle Onassis. Now he  looks for his gigantic jungle proj­ ect to produce 5-million cu. yd. of  lumber by 1986. Production,  mainly for export to the U. S. and  Europe, will begin in 1977.  Having built a fortune in such  varied fields as shipping, savings  and loan associations, hotels, real  estate, mining, and petrochem­ icals, Ludwig dreamed for years  of harvesting equatorial forests  for timber. He had first picked  Nigeria for his site, but a meet­ ing in the early 1960s with Ro­ berto Campos, then ambassador  to Washington, made him set his  course for the Amazon. Campos  became Brazil's chief economic  planner in 1964 and took Ludwig  to see then-President Humberto  Castello Branco, who gave the  project his blessing.  Wood futures. Ludwig believes  that the world is outstripping its  pulp and wood supplies, and that  the traditional source in forests  BUSINESS WEEK: July 31, 1971 of Northern spruce cannot last. He is  betting that the new source will be  equatorial forests, but the secret of  success must be uniform trees.  The tree that Ludwig has picked to  fill the bill is the Gmelina arborea, an  Asian species, also grown in Africa.  The fast-growing, medium-density  hardwood is suitable for furniture, ve­ neer, matches, construction, and—most  importantly—for wood pulp.  Ludwig got his project moving in  March, 1967, when he took over Jari'  Florestal e Agropecuaria (Jarf For- V A /  Surinam V Guiana' Daniel Ludwig's supersize tree farm  sot i c Oc< •  Soulh  America  \__Guyana /  / ) (French  i /  / / L ^> % W  r' y> AmaPa  9> T a z / /  Am* Para  Ludwig's tract Beletll  9 .  Manaus  Camera-shy Ludwig in a rare portrait (1963). estry & Ranching Co.), a small Bra­ zilian trader in rubber, nuts, and hides.  Jari' then proceeded to buy up land in  the state of Para and the territory of  Amapa on the Jari' River, 250 mi. from  the port city of Belem.  At the site, called Monte Dourado,  900 Ludwig employees have planted  61,000 acres of seedlings this year.  They have built more than 100 mi. of  all-weather road to clearings where  sawmills and pulp mills will rise and  where an eventual 2,000 workers will  be housed.  In a mist. A thick fog of secrecy  has settled over Monte Dourado.  The Jari' office in Rio is not listed  in the lobby directory and has no  sign on its door. And Jari oper­ ations are veiled, in turn, behind  another Ludwig front called  Entre Rios Comercio e Adminis- tracao.  These secretive methods upset  some Brazilians. "I just can't un­ derstand all this secrecy," com­ plains an official of Brazil's Ama­ zon Development Agency. But  Brazil is letting Ludwig have his  way because it wants the Ama­ zon basin opened up.  Ludwig has run into other  problems, though. During last  year's rainy season, floods swept  away some 4-million seedlings. In  the dry season, so much rain fell  that it delayed planting. And, in  some respects, the Gmelina's  growth has been disappointing.  In Brazilian soil, it tends to  sprout branches too low, making  its lumber too knotty.  But Ludwig expected prob­ lems, and he has not been dis­ mayed by the century-long  record of failures in the Amazon.  Greening. Contrary to popular be­ lief, jungle soil is extremely frag­ ile. Its nutrients are leached out  by heavy rains, and cleared ter­ rain can quickly erode into a  rocklike shale. Ludwig must dis­ cover what can be done with such  soil on a large scale. So far, the  Gmelina has been growing to a  phenomenal 15 ft. to 18 ft. in only  18 months. But the crucial an­ swers will only begin to come in  BUSINESS ABROAD AGR 8 Forestry2 Daniel K. Ludwig is investing over $30 million in a large-scale reforestation project in Brazil‘s Amazon, targeting a total of $60 million. He aims to cultivate the Gmelina arborea tree for lumber and wood pulp by 1986. Ludwig‘s venture has drawn attention for its secrecy and scale, with operations facing challenges like flooding and soil issues.

When SUDENE's 34/18 program of investment incentives  for private industry first began to take hold a few  years ago, many of the states entered into competition  with each other by offering supplementary incentives,  tax exemptions, special financing or industrial sites  at nominal cost in order to attract new industries to  their cities. The states later agreed that such  competition was divisive and hindered the development  of the region as a whole. They further agreed to  standardize state government assistance to new industry  to the extent possible.  2. This phase of cooperation, of pulling together for  the benefit of the region as a whole is probably best  illustrated by the following example: At a SUDENE  Deliberative Council meeting in November, 1967, the  Aluminum Co. of Canada requested permission of the  Council to relocate from Pernambuco to Bahia its  already approved project for an aluminum extrusion  plant. The Governor of Pernambuco complained to the  Council that he saw no need for the change but, he  recommended that in the interest of overall regional  development the Council should approve the request in  order to allow investors free choice of location and  thereby make the region more attractive to private  investment. Steinmetz  Amconsul BELEH  Leopoldo TAYLHARDAT Sotillo, Venezuelan Consul, Manaus  My apologies for not vtriting sooner about Taylhardat, However, since  I have the opportunity to have this carried to Recife and then to Rio  her goes. He  looks like a Latin Santa Claus: UOish, about 5»9" and 2U0 lbs. with a  huge beer belly. He is talkative, outgoing and very gregarious.  Unfortunately, I did not find an appropriate moment to comer him  and in an inocent way get his views on the border problem and idiat  has been happening lately. In group conversations the following came  to light: Prior to Manaus (his second post), he was assigned to Arauca.  Colombia on the Venezuelan Border for five years. There is not much  legitimate trade between his consular district and Venezeula and few  if any Venezuelan citizens residing in Amazonas, Roraima, Rondonia  and Acre, the states and territories that coagjrise his district.  Accordingly, his consular work must consist of issuiga few visas for  the weekly Varig flight to Caraczo.  Manaus, as you are aware, is the best base for him to keep his govern­ ment informed of Brazilian activities in Western Amazcmia. He does  this for sure, but still there ronains tBe questiaa of vhat he is up  to. Marshall Whitlock, out Consular Agent, states he does quite a  bit of driving as she had brought several sets of tires from Marshall's  firm since his arrival.SIKHHDBKGmffil^^ Unless he spends a lot of  time driving around Manaus the only other possibilities would be  the 286 kilometers betwe«i Manaus and Itacoatiara on the Amazon River,  an 8 hour trip during the dry season, or the few kilometers of the  BR-17ii in sae towards the Alalau River on the Roraima Border, or he  mi^t even be buying tires at a diplomatic price for friends. All  this might add up to KfiBSafflgG nothing? however, there are a few  pokers in the fire and I will keep you posted.  By the way, Belem still is not receiving info copies on the Guyana- Venezuela traffice. Is there anything you can do?  CONFIDMTIAL POL 6 On January 8, 1970, William Balicer, stationed in Manaus, described Venezuelan Consul Leopoldo Taylhardat as a sociable figure who previously worked on the Colombian border. Balicer noted the lack of trade between territories in his consulate district and the absence of Venezuelan citizens there. He expressed curiosity about Taylhardat‘s activities and sought assistance with communication issues concerning Guyana-Venezuela traffic.

ANALYSIS BRANCH  AmConGen RECIFE date: January 9, 1967  Bi-Weekly Summary (December 16 - 31)  Table of Contents  Rural Workers on Strike  "Democrats" Lose Student Elections in Pernambuco  French Faux Pas  JORNAL DO COMMERCIO Supports Cabo Strike  Press Law Denounced  The Mysterious Mister X  Rural Workers on Strike  1. Rural workers in the Recife suburb of Cabo refused to  report to work on December 13 in an attempt to force their  employers to pay them back wages averaging to Cr$90,000 per  worker.. Approximately 1500 rural workers are participating  in the strike which, at this writing, still continues without  promise of settlement.  2. At issue in the dispute is the failure of the sugar cane  producers to pay the minimum wage scale established by the  Federal government in March 1966. Union officials claim  that virtually none of the state's 120,000 rural workers are  receiving the legal minimum of Cr$l800 per day. Many  employers, it is alleged, have paid no salaries at all for  four or five weeks while others are paying all or part of  the worker's wages in scrip good only at company stores,  many of which have little or no merchandise for sale. The workers demand back wages averaging Cr$90,000 and claim that employers have largely failed to adhere to the federal minimum wage established in March 1966.

Solicita sementes de arroz 0 : Solicita sementes de arroz.  Prezado Senhor  Em decorreneia da informaqao transmitida pela  publicaqao "Release Two New Rice Varieties for Latin A- merica", do Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical  (CIAT), a Diretoria do Instituto de Pesquisa Agropecua- y* /  ria do Leste, deste Departamento, com sede em Cruz das  Almas, Bahia, mostou-se interessada em obter essas va - riedades de arroz, nos termosda copia que remetemos em  a.nexo.  Devido ao interesse assim demonstrado, consul  tamos e solicitamos os bons oficios de V.Sa. no sentido  de obter do CIAT o material basico dos cultivares IR 22  e CICA 4 y citados.  Agradecendo antecipadamente pela atenqao que  possamos merecer de V.Sa., reiteramos os protestos de  estima e distinta consideraqao.  OTTO LYRA SCHRADER  Diretor da DPF  Anexo: copia de expediente AGR4-1 Rice Seeds (CIAT) The Instituto de Pesquisa Agropecuária do Leste, based in Cruz das Almas, Bahia, expressed interest in obtaining new rice varieties (IR 22 and CICA 4) following a CIAT publication. They requested assistance to acquire the basic materials and thanked the recipient for their consideration. Signed by Otto Lyra Schrader, Director of DPF, with an attached copy of the request.

Direction of our Agriculture UNCLASSIFIED A-609  Rio do Janeiro  Begs 2  o&y also have resulted from Governrsant policy to hold beef prices  low for the benefit of consumer a. This policy made Brazilian beef  uaare ccsspetitive in the world market and has encouraged farmers to  sell their animals rather than keep them for future herd expansion.  "Direction of our Agric ult>ire"  "In view of rapid population growth and of {growth of our per capita  income, there is an interest in knowing if Brazilian agric at oral  production will be capable of increasing during tee next few .years  sufficiently to keep pace with anticipated demand. Thus, the recent  release by the GoMlio Vargas Foundation of a study which presents  projections of supply and demand for Brazilian agricultural products  to 1975 io very timely.  "The study was carefully prepared and was based on extensive field  research, Conauiaptim tendencies were based on a survey of Y,J10 'urban  family budgets in different cities fed on 1,359 rural family budgets.  Supply tendencies wore based on a stud:/ of 2,165 farm units located in  Rio Grande do Sul, Santa Caterim, SSo Paulo, Mime Geyais, Espirito  Santo, Beroauibuea, and Gears!  "The principal conclusion of the study is teat between i960 and 1975  agricultural production will Increase at a lower rate than internal  demand. During these 15 years, production should increase about 75  percent while demand increases about 31 percent. This difference is  not very large, but it is sufficiently large to give cm concern if  one considers that Brasil is one of the countries most abundantly  endowed with agricultural resources. The study recognizes this, but  forecasts teat the growth of cultivated area will be only about 3.5 to  4 percent annually which is leas than tee 4.5 percent annual growth  rate between 1350 and i960. The reason given for this assumption is  that 'in the present stage of Brazilian agricultural development the  expansion of cultivated area, within the existing structure, appears  to be reaching a point of saturation.'  "According to the study, tee discrepancy between production and demand  for agricultural products should result only in an almost proportional  growth in Imports, Imports which represented 4 percent of domestic  demand for agricultural products in i960 should grew a little more slow­ ly then internal demand, thus representing 3.6 percent in 19Y5« This  indicates teat our self-sufficiency in food should improve a little  through impart substitution.  UNCLASSIFIED AGR2 Agricultural Economics 1 Brazil‘s policy to maintain low beef prices has made Brazilian beef uncompetitive globally, prompting farmers to sell animals instead of expanding herds. A recent study by the Getúlio Vargas Foundation projects that from 1960 to 1975, agricultural production will increase by 75% while demand rises by 31%, raising concerns about food self-sufficiency and imports.

Possible agricultural projects for Northeast. OPTIONAL FORM NO. 10  MAY 1962 EDITION  GSA FPMR (41 CFR) 101-11.6  UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL  Memorandum FILE COPY C3. j^^s  TO : William L. Rodgers, Chief, ARDO  FROM : Russell Desrosiers, Agr. Prod. Advisor  SUBJECT: Possible agricultural projects for Northeast. DATE: October 31, 1969  * 1 • Seed production.  X The production of disease-free,,seed is an industry that can be  developed in the Northeast on semi-arid lands where irrigation is  available. Seed for use throughout the country, and for export,  could be produced. The advantage of the area for this purpose is  that, with high temperature and little or no rainfall, many diseases  which otherwise might prosper and be carried in or on the seed to  infect future crop would not appear at all. Associated business of  seed processing, storage and shipment would develop.  2. Corn and sorghum growing.  Sorghum, being adapted to drought conditions, might be used to  extend the growing season. ^fUse of hi-lysine corn should be encouraged  as soon as this is available. Demonstrations of this corn, and of  its use as hog and poultry feed should be started now. For the small  farmer who grows corn to feed his family, hi-lysine corn can mean  the difference between adequate and inadequate protein nutrition. - y  3. Bean production.  Bean production is a possibility for those areas with adequate  rainfall and, preferably, conditions of terrain suitable for mechani­ zation. No difficulty should be experienced in timing the harvest to  fall in dry weather.  4. Cashew Nut.  This tree is native to the tropics of Central and South America,  although India has become the most important center of production. The  Cashew offers considerable possibility for development. This tree  produces several products. The cashew "apple" is not a true fruit, but  is the swollen peduncle. The true fruit is the kidney-shaped structure  attached to this. The kernel extracted from this is the cashew nut of  commerce. The nut shell has two walls separated by a honeycomb structure  containing a liquid, having an irritant effect on the skin, which is  known as Cashew Nut Shell Liquid. This material is an important source  of natural phenols and is used in the preparation of lubricants, insecti­ cides, plastics, electrical insulation varnishes, and a bonding agent  for brake linings. The cashew "apple" may be eaten fresh or as preserves  and is used for juice.  2.  Buy U.S. Savings Bonds Regularly on the Payroll Savings Plan AGR NE AGRICULTURAL PROGRAM General Correspondence The memo discusses potential agricultural projects for Northeast U.S. It highlights seed production on semi-arid land, emphasizes drought-resistant corn and sorghum, and suggests bean cultivation where rainfall permits. Additionally, it proposes developing the cashew nut industry, noting its diverse products and commercial uses, including food and industrial applications. The document underscores the region‘s agricultural opportunities.

D.K. Ludwig Plans to Harvest a Jungle Business abroad  BRAZIL  D. K. Ludwig plans to harvest a jungle  34 Multibillionaire Daniel K. Ludwig,  never a man to plan on a small scale,  has a monumental new gamble going  in Brazil's Amazon basin. In the last  four years he has sown more than $30- million into a vast commercial refores­ tation scheme on a 2.4-million acre  tract. Ultimately he will put at least  $60-million into his huge tree farm, but  already the 74-year-old U. S. tycoon has  become the biggest investor in one of  the world's last frontiers.  Ludwig is taking a plunge into a  realm of tropical agriculture never be­ fore attempted on such a scale.  And the scheme, operating under  the shroud of secrecy that is a  Ludwig trademark, has Brazil­ ians fascinated. "The project is so  grandiose that you would expect  it only from a national govern­ ment," says an American diplo­ mat in Brazil. "Ludwig is accus­ tomed to investing in lunatic  adventures, and just as accus­ tomed to having them pay off,"  says noted Brazilian economist  Roberto Campos.  Ludwig moves with the bold­ ness of a Howard Hughes and  owns more shipping tonnage  than Aristotle Onassis. Now he  looks for his gigantic jungle proj­ ect to produce 5-million cu. yd. of  lumber by 1986. Production,  mainly for export to the U. S. and  Europe, will begin in 1977.  Having built a fortune in such  varied fields as shipping, savings  and loan associations, hotels, real  estate, mining, and petrochem­ icals, Ludwig dreamed for years  of harvesting equatorial forests  for timber. He had first picked  Nigeria for his site, but a meet­ ing in the early 1960s with Ro­ berto Campos, then ambassador  to Washington, made him set his  course for the Amazon. Campos  became Brazil's chief economic  planner in 1964 and took Ludwig  to see then-President Humberto  Castello Branco, who gave the  project his blessing.  Wood futures. Ludwig believes  that the world is outstripping its  pulp and wood supplies, and that  the traditional source in forests  BUSINESS WEEK: July 31, 1971 of Northern spruce cannot last. He is  betting that the new source will be  equatorial forests, but the secret of  success must be uniform trees.  The tree that Ludwig has picked to  fill the bill is the Gmelina arborea, an  Asian species, also grown in Africa.  The fast-growing, medium-density  hardwood is suitable for furniture, ve­ neer, matches, construction, and—most  importantly—for wood pulp.  Ludwig got his project moving in  March, 1967, when he took over Jari'  Florestal e Agropecuaria (Jarf For- V A /  Surinam V Guiana' Daniel Ludwig's supersize tree farm  sot i c Oc< •  Soulh  America  \__Guyana /  / ) (French  i /  / / L ^> % W  r' y> AmaPa  9> T a z / /  Am* Para  Ludwig's tract Beletll  9 .  Manaus  Camera-shy Ludwig in a rare portrait (1963). estry & Ranching Co.), a small Bra­ zilian trader in rubber, nuts, and hides.  Jari' then proceeded to buy up land in  the state of Para and the territory of  Amapa on the Jari' River, 250 mi. from  the port city of Belem.  At the site, called Monte Dourado,  900 Ludwig employees have planted  61,000 acres of seedlings this year.  They have built more than 100 mi. of  all-weather road to clearings where  sawmills and pulp mills will rise and  where an eventual 2,000 workers will  be housed.  In a mist. A thick fog of secrecy  has settled over Monte Dourado.  The Jari' office in Rio is not listed  in the lobby directory and has no  sign on its door. And Jari oper­ ations are veiled, in turn, behind  another Ludwig front called  Entre Rios Comercio e Adminis- tracao.  These secretive methods upset  some Brazilians. "I just can't un­ derstand all this secrecy," com­ plains an official of Brazil's Ama­ zon Development Agency. But  Brazil is letting Ludwig have his  way because it wants the Ama­ zon basin opened up.  Ludwig has run into other  problems, though. During last  year's rainy season, floods swept  away some 4-million seedlings. In  the dry season, so much rain fell  that it delayed planting. And, in  some respects, the Gmelina's  growth has been disappointing.  In Brazilian soil, it tends to  sprout branches too low, making  its lumber too knotty.  But Ludwig expected prob­ lems, and he has not been dis­ mayed by the century-long  record of failures in the Amazon.  Greening. Contrary to popular be­ lief, jungle soil is extremely frag­ ile. Its nutrients are leached out  by heavy rains, and cleared ter­ rain can quickly erode into a  rocklike shale. Ludwig must dis­ cover what can be done with such  soil on a large scale. So far, the  Gmelina has been growing to a  phenomenal 15 ft. to 18 ft. in only  18 months. But the crucial an­ swers will only begin to come in  BUSINESS ABROAD AGR 8 Forestry2 Daniel K. Ludwig is investing over $30 million in a large-scale reforestation project in Brazil‘s Amazon, targeting a total of $60 million. He aims to cultivate the Gmelina arborea tree for lumber and wood pulp by 1986. Ludwig‘s venture has drawn attention for its secrecy and scale, with operations facing challenges like flooding and soil issues.

It is a widely held opinion, at least in the North, that Para was the  state most benefited by the Revolution of March 1961*. long abandoned, ig­ nored and generally known only for *he Brazil nuts which bear its name  (Castanha do Para), the State had become a haven for government corruption,  peculation, graft and contraband. The Revolution brought with it sweeping  changes and a political leader of the first order, Jarbas Passarinho, an  Amy Colonel serving in Belem, Appointed Governor, Passarinho dedicated  his administration to cleaning up and moralizing the state governmental  machine, to providing and improving basic public services and to boosting  economic development. Even his opponents admit that Para began to advance  during his tiro years in office. Along with Passarinho, another Army offi­ cer, Alacid Nunes, was chosen to head the municipal government of Belem,  Nunes was confronted with a city which had been supported in great part by  the movement of contraband, now largely cut off by the Revolution, He also  made numerous changes, particularly in the city's public works departments,  and quickly became known as a good administrator. Because of his record as  Mayor, and the city's noticeable progress during his administration, Nunes  was an almost natural choice to succeed Passarinho as Governor, In contrast  2/ 1  Exempted from automatic decontrol,  — liWM 6WienP5E  B2 DS-323 -J  FOR DEPT. Nunes, in particular, became known for his effective administration in Belém, facilitating the city‘s progress during his tenure.

D.K. Ludwig Plans to Harvest a Jungle Business abroad  BRAZIL  D. K. Ludwig plans to harvest a jungle  34 Multibillionaire Daniel K. Ludwig,  never a man to plan on a small scale,  has a monumental new gamble going  in Brazil's Amazon basin. In the last  four years he has sown more than $30- million into a vast commercial refores­ tation scheme on a 2.4-million acre  tract. Ultimately he will put at least  $60-million into his huge tree farm, but  already the 74-year-old U. S. tycoon has  become the biggest investor in one of  the world's last frontiers.  Ludwig is taking a plunge into a  realm of tropical agriculture never be­ fore attempted on such a scale.  And the scheme, operating under  the shroud of secrecy that is a  Ludwig trademark, has Brazil­ ians fascinated. "The project is so  grandiose that you would expect  it only from a national govern­ ment," says an American diplo­ mat in Brazil. "Ludwig is accus­ tomed to investing in lunatic  adventures, and just as accus­ tomed to having them pay off,"  says noted Brazilian economist  Roberto Campos.  Ludwig moves with the bold­ ness of a Howard Hughes and  owns more shipping tonnage  than Aristotle Onassis. Now he  looks for his gigantic jungle proj­ ect to produce 5-million cu. yd. of  lumber by 1986. Production,  mainly for export to the U. S. and  Europe, will begin in 1977.  Having built a fortune in such  varied fields as shipping, savings  and loan associations, hotels, real  estate, mining, and petrochem­ icals, Ludwig dreamed for years  of harvesting equatorial forests  for timber. He had first picked  Nigeria for his site, but a meet­ ing in the early 1960s with Ro­ berto Campos, then ambassador  to Washington, made him set his  course for the Amazon. Campos  became Brazil's chief economic  planner in 1964 and took Ludwig  to see then-President Humberto  Castello Branco, who gave the  project his blessing.  Wood futures. Ludwig believes  that the world is outstripping its  pulp and wood supplies, and that  the traditional source in forests  BUSINESS WEEK: July 31, 1971 of Northern spruce cannot last. He is  betting that the new source will be  equatorial forests, but the secret of  success must be uniform trees.  The tree that Ludwig has picked to  fill the bill is the Gmelina arborea, an  Asian species, also grown in Africa.  The fast-growing, medium-density  hardwood is suitable for furniture, ve­ neer, matches, construction, and—most  importantly—for wood pulp.  Ludwig got his project moving in  March, 1967, when he took over Jari'  Florestal e Agropecuaria (Jarf For- V A /  Surinam V Guiana' Daniel Ludwig's supersize tree farm  sot i c Oc< •  Soulh  America  \__Guyana /  / ) (French  i /  / / L ^> % W  r' y> AmaPa  9> T a z / /  Am* Para  Ludwig's tract Beletll  9 .  Manaus  Camera-shy Ludwig in a rare portrait (1963). estry & Ranching Co.), a small Bra­ zilian trader in rubber, nuts, and hides.  Jari' then proceeded to buy up land in  the state of Para and the territory of  Amapa on the Jari' River, 250 mi. from  the port city of Belem.  At the site, called Monte Dourado,  900 Ludwig employees have planted  61,000 acres of seedlings this year.  They have built more than 100 mi. of  all-weather road to clearings where  sawmills and pulp mills will rise and  where an eventual 2,000 workers will  be housed.  In a mist. A thick fog of secrecy  has settled over Monte Dourado.  The Jari' office in Rio is not listed  in the lobby directory and has no  sign on its door. And Jari oper­ ations are veiled, in turn, behind  another Ludwig front called  Entre Rios Comercio e Adminis- tracao.  These secretive methods upset  some Brazilians. "I just can't un­ derstand all this secrecy," com­ plains an official of Brazil's Ama­ zon Development Agency. But  Brazil is letting Ludwig have his  way because it wants the Ama­ zon basin opened up.  Ludwig has run into other  problems, though. During last  year's rainy season, floods swept  away some 4-million seedlings. In  the dry season, so much rain fell  that it delayed planting. And, in  some respects, the Gmelina's  growth has been disappointing.  In Brazilian soil, it tends to  sprout branches too low, making  its lumber too knotty.  But Ludwig expected prob­ lems, and he has not been dis­ mayed by the century-long  record of failures in the Amazon.  Greening. Contrary to popular be­ lief, jungle soil is extremely frag­ ile. Its nutrients are leached out  by heavy rains, and cleared ter­ rain can quickly erode into a  rocklike shale. Ludwig must dis­ cover what can be done with such  soil on a large scale. So far, the  Gmelina has been growing to a  phenomenal 15 ft. to 18 ft. in only  18 months. But the crucial an­ swers will only begin to come in  BUSINESS ABROAD AGR 8 Forestry2 Daniel K. Ludwig is investing over $30 million in a large-scale reforestation project in Brazil‘s Amazon, targeting a total of $60 million. He aims to cultivate the Gmelina arborea tree for lumber and wood pulp by 1986. Ludwig‘s venture has drawn attention for its secrecy and scale, with operations facing challenges like flooding and soil issues.

Significance of current and potential exploitation of marine  resources to the economy of Brazil.  Brazil has an average deficit of some 15 grams of animal protein per  capita per diem. The cheapest animal protein sources are sardine and hake  (Cr$128 and Cr$224, respectively, against Cr$275 for milk - these being the  prices of a complete daily ration of animal protein). Sardine and hake are  plentiful in the South, where the protein deficiency is almost nil, and non­ existent in the North, where the protein deficiency is critical. However,  the North is rich in lobster, red snapper, groupers, shrimp. With the US$ 3  obtained by the export of each kilo of lobster to the U.S., Europe or South  Brazil, the North could import eleven (11) kilos of hake from the South,  paying high trucking freight, or about 15 kilos by maritime freight.  Producing fish in the South to send to the North and producing fish in the  North to send to the South could help Brazil solve the food problem. This  requires:  (1) Research - oce'anographical and fishery - north and south,  (2) Better hydrography (to improve navigation routes). Series A  DEPARTMENT OF STATE  WASHINGTON  SECRET  To:  From:  Subject:  Reference: G/PM - Mr. Kitchen I June 9> 1965  ARA - Jack H. Vaughn/^/  Ship Loan Legislation  Your Memorandum of June 4, 1965  /With regard to your proposed memorandum to the  Secretary, I feel that we would be taking the wrong  ^jfeack in developing an order of priorities regarding  A/the' ship loan bills, and I believe the Secretary  /^should recommend approval of all three bills to  Senator Russell. Furthermore, I feel strongly that  the memorandum dismisses the ARA case far too lightly.  We have over a period of years attempted to  standardize on Fletcher class destroyers in the major  South American navies. These navies have made their  ' ^ long-range plans in anticipation of eventual ship loan  \ ' legislation, and such legislation offers them the only 01  reasonable hope of a modest upgrading of their aging  fleets. Brazil is the outstanding example in this  regard, and Ambassador Gordon has put the case forcefully  in Rio telegram 2441 (attached). Indeed, when the  Bra^rttah Foreign Minister called on Secretary Rusk on  April 2, 1965, the ship loan legislation was one of the  items he raised as being of particular importance to his  country8  I would add that, should the ARA bill not pass  while either or both of the others do, the reaction in  South America would be extremely adverse. In the case of  Brazil, which has cooperated with the United States in  an outstanding manner with respect to the Dominican crisis  and the creation of the Inter-American Force, it would be  especially serious.  We V3)  1  r  t5  SECRET DEF 19-8 US-BRAZ On June 9, 1965, Mr. Kitchen expressed concerns about prioritizing ship loan legislation, urging Secretary Rusk to support all three bills. He emphasized the importance of the ARA case, highlighting Brazil‘s reliance on such legislation for fleet upgrades and the potential negative reaction in South America if the ARA bill fails, particularly given Brazil‘s cooperation with the U.S. during the Dominican crisis.

Foreign Office Note COPY Foreign Office Note  Hoo 7^5 BRAS/UA; BRAZIL APRG 1963  The Embassy of the United States of America presents  its compliments to the Ministi^ of Foreign Affairs and has  the honor to inform the Ministry of the desire of the Depart­ ment of St<ite to arrange for a visit to the Port of Recife  from May 8 to 10 of the United States Naval vessel "Spiegel  Groveo"  The "Spiegal Grove" is a saluting ship. It is taking  part in a good-will cruise of South American and African  ports. The commanding officer of the ship is Captain Re £«  Hawthorne, United States Navy, The Commander of United  States Naval Forces, South Atlantic, Rear Admiral J»A. l^ree.  Junior, will be embarked. Daring the  extended pericd of several years that the American Embassy protected  Brazilian interests, the Soviets adamantly refused to release a single  repatriate.  Murillo attributes his Embassy's success to a Soviet desire to  start off on the righ+foot in the period immediately following the  establishment of diplomatic relations. While'pleased with the progress  made so far, Murillo ia not particularly sanguine about the future  since, as he says, "the going gets tougher with each and every case."  At the present time there are over two thousand additional cases awaiting  Soviet documentation. "  One of the more compassionate cases which the Brazilians were able  to bring to a happy conclusion was the Zhilis family. While looking out  for Brazilian interests, this Embassy built up an extensive file on this  family, but we were never able to make the slightest dent with the  Soviet authorities when it came to the question of exit documentation.  After extensive and prolonged maneuvering, the Brazilians were finally  able to secure exit visas for the entire family and they departed Moscow  for Rio De Janeiro on April 2b, 1963. Clearaoces: DIPLOMATIC & CONSULAR REPRESENTATION On May 3, 1963, the Brazilian Embassy reported that it secured exit documents for 60 Brazilian repatriates from the USSR, following the establishment of diplomatic relations. Despite the progress, Second Secretary Jose Murillo de Carvalho noted challenges ahead, with over 2,000 cases pending. A notable success was securing visas for the Zhilis family, who left Moscow for Rio de Janeiro on April 26, 1963.

The Brazilian Catholic Church's Role in "Basic Reform" « . 'UK  C5~  RM/R  / REP A F  ARA EUR FE  N EA CU INR  E P  / IO  L FBO AID  AGR COM FRB  INT LAB TAR  TR XMB AIR  ARMY CIA NAVY  OSD USI A N SA  Drafted by: DEPARTMENT OF STATE  FOR RM USE ONLY  A-662 CONFIDENTIAL  HANDLING INDICATOR  TO  FROM  SUBJECT  RET  r Department of State  NOV 3 0 1963  AmEmbassy RIO DE JANEIRO DATE: November 27, 1963  The Brazilian Catholic Church's Role in "Basic Reform".  Department's A-58, August 12, 1963  SUMMARY FILE  No Action  ARA:LA/BR  R. Burton  JAN 7 1964 The Embassy's view is that the Catholic  Church's limited ability to influence Brazilian  public opinion make it but a marginal factor at  the present time in the debate over reform. It  of course has great potential for good; but, like  other Brazilian institutions, especially political  entities, It is weakened by discord and inertia. *******  Despite the fact that Brazil is the largest Catholic nation  in the world, the role of the Church in Brazilian life has  always been rather circumscribed. Its present position in the  nation is reflected in the rather nominal Catholicism of the  large majority of Brazilians, which leads a prominent Catholic  layman to estimate that 5$ of the Brazilian population are  practicing Catholics and another 5$ attend Church on occasion;  the limited numbers of priests within the country (estimated at  less than one for every 40,000 Brazilians); and the inauspicious  showing of a Church-selected and backed slate of candidates in  the 19o2 Guanabara elections. In effect, the Church today  remains more of a veto group, able to block such legislation as  the adoption of legalized divorce, rather than an active  political force. Nevertheless, two factions within the Church,  one extremely nationalistic and useful to if not openly  cooperating with the far left, and the other moderate and reform- oriented, are coming to play an increasingly important  political role.  •-GROUP 3 - Downgrade after 12-yrs;  net automatically declas^j^^  FO  4 - S2 FOR, DEPT. USE ONLY  jln •Out  POL:TBFriedman/CCCars on/rstp Contents and Classification Approved by: Vl**""  DCM - Minister Mein JC-h pec ff*C. ci earances: USIS - Dr. Boehrer (in draft)  POL/R- Mr. Gardiner (in draft) NON-PARTY BLOCS The Department of State‘s confidential document from November 30, 1963, discusses the Brazilian Catholic Church‘s limited influence on public opinion and reform debates. Despite being the world‘s largest Catholic nation, Brazil‘s Church is weakened by discord and retains a marginal role in politics, primarily acting as a veto against legislation. Two factions within the Church are becoming politically significant.

Brazilian Presidential Letter Concerning Ship Loan Legislation DEPARTMENT OF STATE  ASSISTANT SECRETARY  CONFIDENTIAL  The Secretary September 16, 1965  Loan Legislation ACTION MEMORANDUM  The Brazilian Ambassador has informed the Department  that President Castello Branco has written a letter to  President Johnson concerning the pending ship loan legis­ lation. The letter is now at the Brazilian Embassy in  Washington ready to be delivered. Although the letter's  exact contents are not known, we understand it stresses  the importance of the destroyers to Brazil and requests  President Johnson's assistance in securing passage of the  ship loan legislation.  The Brazilian Ambassador has been holding the letter,  having recommended to his government that it not be delivered  until he could first ascertain that it was timely and that  you and President Johnson would not find it unwelcome. He  does not wish in any way to injure the warm feelings and  respect you and President Johnson have for Brazil, and he  has asked ARA informally to obtain your views in the matter.  Because of the continuing lack of certainty of legis- \\j  lation this session providing for the loan of destroyers to ^  Brazil, and the great importance attached to this matter by  the GOB, we do not believe the Brazilians should be discour- ^  aged from delivering President Castello Branco's letter.  Even though the legislation may fail to pass, they will at ^  least feel they did everything they could and were fully  supported  \ CONFIDENTIAL DEF 19-8 US-BRAZ On September 16, 1965, the Brazilian Ambassador informed the U.S. State Department that President Castello Branco has a letter for President Johnson regarding pending ship loan legislation, emphasizing its importance to Brazil. The Ambassador delayed delivery to assess timing and reception. The Department advises against discouraging the delivery, stressing Brazil‘s commitment, despite potential legislative failure.

Rural workers in the Recife suburb of Cabo refused to  report to work on December 13 in an attempt to force their  employers to pay them back wages averaging to Cr$90,000 per  worker.. Approximately 1500 rural workers are participating  in the strike which, at this writing, still continues without  promise of settlement.  2. At issue in the dispute is the failure of the sugar cane  producers to pay the minimum wage scale established by the  Federal government in March 1966. Union officials claim  that virtually none of the state's 120,000 rural workers are  receiving the legal minimum of Cr$l800 per day. Many  employers, it is alleged, have paid no salaries at all for  four or five weeks while others are paying all or part of  the worker's wages in scrip good only at company stores,  many of which have little or no merchandise for sale. Possible agricultural projects for Northeast. OPTIONAL FORM NO. 10  MAY 1962 EDITION  GSA FPMR (41 CFR) 101-11.6  UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL  Memorandum FILE COPY C3. j^^s  TO : William L. Rodgers, Chief, ARDO  FROM : Russell Desrosiers, Agr. Prod. Advisor  SUBJECT: Possible agricultural projects for Northeast. DATE: October 31, 1969  * 1 • Seed production.  X The production of disease-free,,seed is an industry that can be  developed in the Northeast on semi-arid lands where irrigation is  available. Seed for use throughout the country, and for export,  could be produced. The advantage of the area for this purpose is  that, with high temperature and little or no rainfall, many diseases  which otherwise might prosper and be carried in or on the seed to  infect future crop would not appear at all. Associated business of  seed processing, storage and shipment would develop.  2. Corn and sorghum growing.  Sorghum, being adapted to drought conditions, might be used to  extend the growing season. ^fUse of hi-lysine corn should be encouraged  as soon as this is available. Demonstrations of this corn, and of  its use as hog and poultry feed should be started now. For the small  farmer who grows corn to feed his family, hi-lysine corn can mean  the difference between adequate and inadequate protein nutrition. - y  3. Bean production.  Bean production is a possibility for those areas with adequate  rainfall and, preferably, conditions of terrain suitable for mechani­ zation. No difficulty should be experienced in timing the harvest to  fall in dry weather.  4. Cashew Nut.  This tree is native to the tropics of Central and South America,  although India has become the most important center of production. The  Cashew offers considerable possibility for development. This tree  produces several products. The cashew "apple" is not a true fruit, but  is the swollen peduncle. The true fruit is the kidney-shaped structure  attached to this. The kernel extracted from this is the cashew nut of  commerce. The nut shell has two walls separated by a honeycomb structure  containing a liquid, having an irritant effect on the skin, which is  known as Cashew Nut Shell Liquid. This material is an important source  of natural phenols and is used in the preparation of lubricants, insecti­ cides, plastics, electrical insulation varnishes, and a bonding agent  for brake linings. The cashew "apple" may be eaten fresh or as preserves  and is used for juice.  2.  Buy U.S. Savings Bonds Regularly on the Payroll Savings Plan AGR NE AGRICULTURAL PROGRAM General Correspondence The memo discusses potential agricultural projects for Northeast U.S. It highlights seed production on semi-arid land, emphasizes drought-resistant corn and sorghum, and suggests bean cultivation where rainfall permits. Additionally, it proposes developing the cashew nut industry, noting its diverse products and commercial uses, including food and industrial applications. The document underscores the region‘s agricultural opportunities.

This may have been so because in these issues the  United States was not involved; they were strictly  battles among the Latin Americans.  I. Subregional Groups  The paragraph on subregional groups, as finally agreed,  is Chapter I, paragraph 2.d., of the "Declaration of  the Presidents of America." This reads as follows:  To promote the conclusion of temporary subregional  agreements, with provision for reducing tariffs  within the subregions and harmonizing treatments  toward third nations more rapidly than in the  general agreements, in keeping with the objectives  of regional integration. Loan Program for Dairy Cattle Improvement OFFICIAL  FILE COPY  Michael N. Galli, Deputy Chief, ARDO September 12, 1969  Boyd T. Whittle, Asst. Agr. Prod. Advisor  Loan Program for Dairy Cattle Improvement.  Following is historical information related to dairy cattle programs in  Brazil plus my thoughts on how outside financing might be benifical in  improving these programs.  I. NUMBER OF DAIRY CATTLE, CONCENT RATION. PRODUCTION  The Ministry of Agriculture estimated Brazil's cattle population at 88  million head as of December 31, 1967. Other Ministry figures indicate  that the National Dairy Herd was composed of 20.000.000 head in 1963,  of which 5.500.000 head were in lactation. The relatively high number  of head considered as making up the dairy herd may have been arrived at  by considering any bovine milked at some time during the year as being  a part of the dairy herd. The Ministry's estimates show that 30% of  the total herd is composed of cows. This would be roughly 25 million  head, and if as the Ministry figures indicate, 20 million head make up  the dairy herd, one of these figures is obviously incorrect. In the  absence of accurate data on the number of cattle in the national dairy  herd, it would seem that almost any estimate would be reasonable.  Perhaps 10 million head would be a good figure for what are considered  dairy cattle.  Most of what can be considered milk cows are located in the states of  Mines Gerais, Sao Paulo and Rio Grande do Sul. In 1966 the amount of  milk produced in these states was respectively 2.040.292, 1.429.800, and  528.299 tons. Total cattle numbers were 19.500.000, 11.300.000, and  II. 200.000 head respectively. These figures indicate that Sao Paulo has  either the greatest number of dairy cows or the highest productivity, or  both, with Mines following. Rio Grande do Sul apparently has a high  percentage of cattle "not for milk" in its herd.  II. LOSSES FROM TUBERCULOSIS  There is little information available on incidence of tuberculosis in  either beef or dairy cattle herds. In a 1965 survey of 5 dairy coopera­ tives located in Minas Gerais, PLANAM (Piano de Me1horamento da Alimen- ta?2o e do Manejo do Gado Leiteiro) found that among 9 77 dairy producers,  400 of which were contacted in the survey, only 11% were testing for  tuberculosis. Only 19% were testing for brucelosis.  2 AGR 10-2 Disease and Pests 1 On September 12, 1969, Michael N. Galli discussed the dairy cattle program in Brazil, noting an estimated cattle population of 88 million and a dairy herd of around 20 million. Most dairy cattle are in Minas Gerais, Sao Paulo, and Rio Grande do Sul. He highlighted the lack of data on tuberculosis incidence, with only 11% of dairy producers testing for it.

Weekly Summary (May 27-June 2) UNCLASSIFIED 2  serious was the threatened complete breakdown of the city's  water supply as slides and erosion removed the underpinnings  of the Monjope aqueduct which normally supplies the North  side of the city but which had to be mobilized to make up  for deficiency resulting from the destruction of the Gurjau  dam which furnishes water to the South side of the city.  2. Comment: This is the second year in a row that Recife has  suffered heavily from rains and floods. Unusually heavy  rainfall, combined with the almost insupperable drainage  problems presented by the city's location at sea level (and,  at times, below sea level), were certainly at the root of  the city's problems, but the loss of life and home was caused  solely by perilous and insalubrious location of mucambos  (shanties) on hillsides and on the edges of the rivers and  swamps.  B. Special SUDENE Council Meeting Declares "State of Public  Calami tv"  3. Recife and its suburbs of Olinda, Jaboatao, and Cabo, as  well as Salvador and Santo Amaro, Bahia, were declared by  the SUDENE Deliberative Council to be areas of "public calamity"  in a special meeting held behind closed doors. Relief work  was to be supervised by Minister of Coordination Cordeiro de  Farias who arrived in Salvador on June 1 and was expected in  Recife before the end of the week.  4. Comment: Effective coordination among the various private  and public relief agencies proved difficult to achieve. Only  on May 31, four days after the beginning of the intense rains,  were specific responsibilities assigned. Work was further  hampered by inadequate spending authority. The US government  responded to appeals for assistance by providing one ton of  charque (dried meat), 2,000 cotton blankets and 2,600 bars of  soap and authorizing the use of Food for Peace stocks for  emergency feeding.  C. June Meeting of SUDENE Deliberative Council  5. The June meeting of the SUDENE Deliberative Council was  marked by record brevity and record paucity of attendance as  all but one governor - Virgilio Tavora, who presided over the  UNCLASSIFIED  DECLASSIFIED  Authority \Wrt£5oQ6- GENERAL REPORTS & STATISTICS Recife faced severe challenges due to heavy rains and floods, leading to a potential water supply breakdown. Following the destruction of the Gurja dam, areas were declared in “public calamity“ by the SUDENE Council. Relief efforts struggled with coordination and funding, prompting aid from the US government in the form of food and supplies.

November 17, 1966  Reference airgram requested by December 15> 19^6 summary comments on ~~'  Marine Science and technology in Brazil. Consequently, through the inter­ mediary of Commander Thomas E. Stixrud, USNR, the Embassy contacted  Comandante Paulo de Castro Moreira da Silva, one of Brazil's foremost  oceanographers regarding the desired information, who offered the following  statements:  a. Significance of current and potential exploitation of marine  resources to the economy of Brazil.  Brazil has an average deficit of some 15 grams of animal protein per  capita per diem. The cheapest animal protein sources are sardine and hake  (Cr$128 and Cr$224, respectively, against Cr$275 for milk - these being the  prices of a complete daily ration of animal protein). Sardine and hake are  plentiful in the South, where the protein deficiency is almost nil, and non­ existent in the North, where the protein deficiency is critical. However,  the North is rich in lobster, red snapper, groupers, shrimp. With the US$ 3  obtained by the export of each kilo of lobster to the U.S., Europe or South  Brazil, the North could import eleven (11) kilos of hake from the South,  paying high trucking freight, or about 15 kilos by maritime freight.  Producing fish in the South to send to the North and producing fish in the  North to send to the South could help Brazil solve the food problem. This  requires:  (1) Research - oce'anographical and fishery - north and south,  (2) Better hydrography (to improve navigation routes). In,„  FROM : Amconsulate SALVADOR  SUBJECT: Bahia Governor Renews Pacification Theme  REF : SLV-7, Feb. 16, 1968; A-24, July 24, 1968  r RS/AN  ANALYSIS BRANCH  DATE: September 6, 1968  During the past month Governor Luiz Viana Filho took two more  dramatic steps in his campaign to bring about political harmony  in Brazil.  Speaking at the Political Reporters's Club in Rio de Janeiro  on September 2, Viana said it is of vital importance to create  a climate of understanding which will isolate radicalism and  permit a marshalling of forces for the solution of national  problems. He said an erroneous impression exists in Brazil  that the country is standing still, accomplishing nothing,  whereas the Federal and State Governments are making steady- progress. Viana commented that the economic situation is good  and the fight against inflation has brought appreciable re­ sults, but wide-spread discontent continues to exist because  the political machine is out of kilter. Political crisis is  in the atmosphere, he continued, and an effort must be made  towards establishing national unity, i.e., pacification. Na­ tional discussion of the Strategic Development Plan for Brazil  would help towards a better public understanding of what the  government is doing, he concluded.  The Consulate has been informed that Governor Viana recently  sent a letter to President Costa e Silva in which he attempts  to revive his pacification program. Though given only in  broad outline, the Governor's proposal is nevertheless better  articulated than heretofore. His main theme involves the for­ mation of a National Governors Front which would launch a mas- l_sive publicity campaign to distract the attention of the Bra- j  LIMITED OFFICIAL USE  DS-323 FOR QEPT. USE ONLY  • Out  POL:HRBird:ym )/6/68 Contents and Classification Approved by:  Clearances: PROVINCIAL, MUNICIPAL & STATE GOVERNMENT Governor Luiz Viana Filho has emphasized the need for political harmony in Brazil, asserting that the Federal and State Governments are making progress despite public discontent. He advocates for a National Governors Front and a publicity campaign to address misunderstandings about the government’s efforts. Viana‘s approach aims to isolate radicalism and foster national unity amidst a political crisis.

The sessions  recieved no local press or radio coverage because of what was considered  to be an unjustified attack on Govenor Celso Ramos as a fascist and  because of the leftist point of view expressed by some student leaders  and by visiting Federal Deputies Neiva Moreira and Leonel Brizola.  The deputies preached revolution. The impact was limited to the audience  and this varied from the students' mild enthusiasim to the workers' hard  working claque. End Summary  A meeting of student leaders representing Brazil's university  student organizations affliated with the National Student Union met  in Florianopolis from January 5 to 1Z. The conference was well  advertized by a full page spread in the local newspaper "A Gazeta"  and by leaflets. Both also publicized the fact that Deputies Leonel  Brizola, Paulo de Tarso, Max da Costa Santos and Neiva Moreira  would not only attend but would also address the meetings. Leaflets  also issued by the Peoples-Workers-Student Front invited the  population to go to the airport to meet Brizola and offered transportation  in special buses. The public was also invited to attend the plenary  sessions held at night in the Law School.  It quickly became apparent that the meetings were not concerned  with student affairs but were really political in nature. Unions demanding 8o percent increase over October 196k contract; Furtado  had suggested 55 percent, and one leading mill owner privately suggested willingness  grant no more than 20 percent. Furtado had successfully balked efforts Textile Union  call strike last July and October. Labor Leaders Official - Infonaal American Consulate  Belera, Para, Brazil  June 26, 196ii  UHCUSSIFIED  Dear Herbert:  I regret that I have not been able to forward to you the semi­ annual labor suimnary. Unfortunately, the Consulate does iK>t have  professional courier semrice and we just recently received the  request for a report covering this period. I believe that our  regular political and economic reporting will have kept you in  touch with day-to-day happenings on the Northern labor scene.  However, there follows a summary of events for the last six months  which, while late, I hope will still be of service to your office.  The early months of the year, until the overthrow of the Goulart  regimd, were marked by increased leftist union agitation as the local  CGT parroted the national program of more and more nationalizations  of private enteirprise and support for Goulart. There is no doubt  that the local CGT and such leftist-d<Mainat^ unions as PETROBRAS and  the dock workers were buoyed up by national events and led to sponsor  more aggressive leftist demands on the local level. These included  a proposed mass meeting to be personally addressed by President Goulart  for sometime in April (styled after the !4arch 13 Rio de Janeiro rally)  and demands for the nationalization of such local industries as ICOMI  (Con A-U8, llarch 2U, 196U) and the Credit Bank of Amazonia (where  majority interest is already controlled by the Brazilian Government).  The Revolution of April 1 brought to a sharp halt all such  agitation. The actual number of Para labor leaders removed from  leadership in local unions (probably no mre than 20) was small.  But it was this leftist faction which represented the vocal and  active element in Para unionism. Their departure left a virtual  vaccuum in this area which the "democratic" labor movement seems  presently incapable of filling. Thus, from the point of view of at  least political activity, the alrea<fy weak arvi dependent Northern  Brazil labor movement is now considered even weaker.  Herbert W. Baker,^Esquire^  Labor Attache^  American Embassy^  Rio de Janeiro,  UNCLASSIFIED LAB Labor&Manpower On June 26, 196ii, an American consulate letter addressed to Herbert discusses delays in sending a labor summary due to the lack of courier services. It highlights increased leftist union activity prior to the overthrow of Goulart, marked by demands for nationalization. Following the April 1 revolution, leftist leaders were removed, leaving the Northern Brazil labor movement weaker and less politically active.

A confidential telegram from the U.S. Department of State discusses a meeting on October 31, 1965, with Brazilian President Castello Branco. He expressed fatigue but was encouraged by the support from military officers and labor unions. The President is focused on establishing new political parties and announced his new ambassador to Washington. He also mentioned the Soviet ambassador‘s farewell remarks regarding Brazil‘s challenges.

Castello Branco Rejects Re-election or Extension of Mandate  As if to close the recently-renewed debate over the ques­ tion of postponing or modifying the 1966 elections to permit  President Castello Branco to remain in office for an additional  period, the President told an impressive collection of Army  generals last week that he would neither permit his re-election  nor the extension of his mandate. Speaking at a January 18  Military Club annual reunion of the 1921 class of military  academy graduates, the President stated that he was responding  to the "hasty suspicions" of former advocates of continuismo  who now voice shock at talk of an extension of the presidential  mandate and to "veteran and recent admirers of dictatorship for  Brazil". He emphasizes the importance of recognizing the end of a presidential mission amid ongoing discussions about postponing 1966 elections. Other topics include a new Navy minister, political expectations on state elections, and a command shuffle in the Air Force.

Report on Allegations of Torture in Brazil amnesty mieriiauoiiai  0(W^ji U.S.A.  200 WEST 72nd STREET  NEW YORK, N.Y. 10023  Tel.: (212) 724-9907  Report on Allegations  of Torture in Brazil  AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL  The following documents compose the bulk of an intensive and  thorough study of Brazil's alleged violations of the Universal  Declaration of Human Rights. The study has been submitted to  President Garrastazu Medici of Brazil, the United Nations  Human Rights Commission, the Brazilian ^Ambassador to Great  Britain, the Secretary General of the United Nations, and—  jointly with the Latin America Department of the National  Council of Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. and the Division for  Latin America of the United States Catholic Conference—to the  Human Rights Commission of the Organization of American  States It is being .tent to all Uni'ed Slates senators and  congressmen, and to u hundred and iiiiriy-two united Nations  delegations. Amnesty International is an independent, non- sectarian, and non-governmental organization, with in­ ternational headquarters in London and U.S. national  headquarters in New York. It has consultative status with the  United Nations, UNESCO, and the Council of Europe. On  September 5, 1972. the first part of this report, which includes  the names of 1,081 alleged victims of torture in Brazil, was  released. The second part, which appeared shortly thereafter,  contains the names of alleged torturers (see foreword by Sean  MacBride j: In his foreword, Mr. MacBride invites a response  from the Brazilian government. In Brazil, the only responses to  date have been repeated verbal attacks against Amnesty In­ ternational and a new press law forbidding the mention of  Amnesty's name.—The Editor.  Foreword  The Amnesty International inquiry into allegations of torture  in Brazil was carried out in April and May of 1972. As Brazil  has consistently refused to allow representatives of  organizations-such as the Organization of American States  and Amnesty International-to enter the country to investigate  reports of torture, the present report was compiled from  material available in Europe and North America. A  representative of Amnesty International has carefully  considered available documents in an effort to choose only the  most soundly based allegations for inclusion in this report.  As the Amnesty inquiry received no cooperation from the  authorities, its sources of information were necessarily  one-sided. Evaluation of the information received wis* thus based on subjective impressions of the complainant and his  account, viewed in the light of any corroborative or  contradictory evidence available. It was on this basis that the  deposition material was included here and conclusions drawn.  A response from the Brazilian government is invited.  The documents dealing with torture and homicide had beer:  sent to our representative by or on behalf of persons unable,  for various reasons, including continued imprisonment, to  report personally on their experience. In such cases where it  was not possible for the Amnesty representative to interview  those invoived, an effort was nonetheless maae to select  documents which appeared reliable and which were  corroborated by supportive material.  The names of victims and perpetrators of ill treatment  submitted to Amnesty International were so numerous that it  was decided to summarize the bulk of the material in the form  of indices. Two appendices [not included in the 1DOC  edition] have thus been drawn up: the first gives the names of  reported victims, while the second (confidential and available  only to a limited number of international organizations and  officials of the Brazilian government) gives 472 names of those  reported as responsible for ill treatment. Each entry in the two  appendices is cross-referenced to indicate the congruity of  multiple information sources.  The present report, necessarily limited and incomplete, deals  with the period from December 13, 1968 to July 15, 1972.  Although Brazil has not permitted an independent body of  observers to enter the country to investigate such charges, we  feel that such precise and specific accusations have been made  that it is difficult to discount their substance. We ask,  therefore, that the Brazilian government respond to the very  serious charges raised here, and that an independent  commission of inquiry be permitted to enter Brazil in order to  investigate, without restriction, accusations of serious  violations of Articles 5, 9, 18, and 19 of the Universal  Declaration of Human Rights.  Sean MacBride  Chairman  International Executive Committee  Amnesty International SOC 14 HumanRights.RaceRelations 1975 Amnesty International‘s report on torture allegations in Brazil, submitted to various officials and organizations, highlights violations of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Compiled from available information due to the Brazilian government‘s refusal to allow investigations, the report lists 1,081 alleged torture victims and invites a response. It emphasizes the need for an independent inquiry into serious human rights violations.

A telegram from Rio de Janeiro dated June 21, 1963, highlights Brazilian Foreign Minister Evandro Lins e Silva‘s inaugural speech. It outlines Brazil‘s foreign policy principles: promoting independence and development, maintaining non-discriminatory relations, self-determination, recognition of international organizations, and advocating for peace and disarmament. Worry is growing throughout the Foreign Office about  Brazil's international reputation and relations with other  countries as a result of the repressive policies being pursued  by the nation's military rulers. Career diplomats are frustrated  that no one at the Foreign Ministry can do anything to prevent  harm being done to Brazil's international position. Officers at  Itamarati are convinced that the military leaders running Brazil  are absolutely 'uninterested in foreign opinion and unconcerned  about the repercussions their policies might be having. Foreign  Ministry reports about negative foreign reactions are totally  ignored. The Foreign Office is no longer 8 fnetor in the  formulation of Brazilian policy. He also said that he and his  colleagues are resigned to the fact that Foreign Minister  Magalhaes Pinto is just managing to hold on to his .job and is  really powerless.  Turning to recent developments in Brazil, the source stated that  a month ago the general and encouraging Lmpression was that  President Costa e Silva and moderate militarv elements appeared  to be regaining control of the direction of policy. Since our last communication of over a year ago,  I spertfe^most all the year in Brazil helping to organize  the ACCION program in both Eio and Sao Paulo. I can  report that both are getting well-established and  creating strong roots among some 25,000 people of the  favelas of both cities. Boards of Directors of prominent  industrial and professional people have been set up in  both cities, a Brazilian staff picked and trained and  Brazilian field workers are actively engaged in slum  development programs in 10 different favelas. Community  centers, schools, vocational training, small business  and a number of other programs have already been organized. \  The initial organizing phase has taken longer and  been more difficult than we expected, but now we are see­ ing results and it is evident that Brazilians, once they  undertake something, take off with great enthusiasm.  in We found that we were tackling a job considerably more  immense than we faced in Venezuela, a country ten times  the size and with problems more immense and with less re­ sources to handle them.
